awd_titl_txt: Lateral migration of droplets and vesicles in inertial microfluidics
awd_abstract_narration:
Manipulating and positioning small objects like cells or drops in flow is important in industry, biology, and medicine.  The properties of these objects, including size, shape, and softness, often distinguish particles of interest from complex mixtures of many particles.  However, current tools for measuring the deformability or softness of such objects are very limited.  Often, these tools can analyze objects only slowly and in small numbers, so that large heterogeneous samples cannot be processed efficiently.  Alternately, some tools do not allow only objects with certain properties to be selected and collected for further analysis.  This study aims to understand how the mechanical properties of cell-like objects affects their behavior in flow in small channels and relate that behavior to the object's properties.  Experiments and computer simulations will be used to examine cell-like objects undergoing flow.  The results will be used to engineer a rapid, cellular deformability measurement tool that will also allow cell sorting.  Such a device would benefit various biological and clinical applications, such as cancer diagnostics, stem cell research, and drug development.  

This research will identify critical factors that enhance lateral migration of deformable microscale objects and will establish the fundamental understanding required to predict locations of deformable objects with known properties in channel flow. When microscale objects are injected into inertial microfluidics operating at finite particle-Reynolds-number, a balance of opposing, inertial lift forces acting on flowing microscale objects leads to unique lateral and vertical positions in a rectangular microchannel. An additional force also exists away from the channel walls in Poiseuille flow, which locates deformable objects closer to the channel center than rigid ones. By taking particle size into account, the location of objects in the channel can be used to infer their deformability. Also, the inherently high flow speeds at which inertial effects are relevant make inertial microfluidic systems ideal candidates for high-throughput deformability measurements. This study examines behaviors of droplets and vesicles in inertial flow, experimentally and computationally, to explain fundamental aspects of nonlinear particle migration. The experiments span a wide range of parameters and will identify dynamically significant regions of the parameter space, and the simulations will provide non-intrusive access to the flow fields, the balance of forces, and the stability of the flow state.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project provided the foundational knowledge for the development of tunable continuous-flow microfluidic systems that can purify target objects among a large population of heterogeneous samples based on particular mechanical properties of interest. Previously, it was known that soft and deformable microscale objects follow trajectories that are distinctively different from those of their rigid counterparts with the same size when microscale objects are injected into microchannels two to five times larger in widths at high speeds ranging between a few mm/s to cm/s (i.e., inertial flow). This finding provided the means to purify deformable objects from heterogenous populations by utilizing the flow alone and without the need for additional sorting mechanisms that require electrical, magnetic, or optical effects. While promising results have been reported for deformability-based label-free object-sorting systems, such systems are yet to be applicable for the purification of more deformable particles blended in a population comprising various types of objects with indistinguishable sizes. In addition, exhibited lateral migrations resulted from ensemble deformability; thus, individual contributions from viscosity, interfacial tensions, and elasticity remained unknown.

 

This project collected experimental and computational data, providing insights into the dominant contributors that deform flowing objects in flow. Experimental investigations using >80,000 oil droplets with viscosities and interfacial tensions spanning three orders of magnitudes informed that there exists a power law predicting the deformation of the droplets as a function of flow speed, viscosity, droplet size, and interfacial tension. Among all tested parameters, the flow speed and droplet size had the largest influence on droplet deformation when the oil/water mixture exhibited a high tendency for two phases to separate. In contrast, the interfacial tension becomes the dominant predictive factor of droplet deformability when the emulsifiability of the oil/water mixture is high (i.e., stable emulsion).  

 

This project also examined the lateral migration directions of deformable living cells in the inertial flow of Newtonian fluids, viscoelastic fluids, and purely elastic fluids. It was found that the size-dependency of the lateral migration speed was reversed and enhanced from that of Newtonian fluid when cells were suspended in the carrier fluid, exhibiting higher shear thinning effect. This experimental examination of cell behaviors in non-Newtonian inertial flow informed device design guidelines, and a label-free cell purification device for retinal transplantation is currently being constructed to be compliant with FDA regulations for the process of human cells intended for transplantation into human recipients.

 

Several graduate students, undergraduate students with under-represented minority backgrounds, high-school students, and a postdoc were trained in experimental inertial microfluidics developments and computational fluid mechanics. In addition, multiple lab tours to selected high school students were hosted to provoke their STEM interests.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/03/2023
Modified by: Soojung Hur
